channel.title: [C++] Learn how to create a file
channel.description:
Although, you'll have to create a compiler, this does show you how to make a file. Next I might show you how to add ints (math) Written 100% by Roger
#include //Prepares it for compiling int Add (int x2, int y2) { // Creates a int that is x2, and y2 cout << "Hello " << x2 << " and " << y2 << " "; /*The code << y2 << is like the same as doing [i]" + intHere + "[/i], you can add any int in between the << and it'll write the int's value*/ } //Ends the int ADD void voiName() { //Since its called in the start, anything below is for the void that is going to be called cout << "n/This void was called.n/"; /*This will only display when its called, and it'll be on a new fresh line as the [i]n/[/i] is called to create a new line.*/ } //This ends the void int main() { //This is the main int, it holds everything, its like the [i]server.java[/i] except it does nothing but hold cout << "Chat things here.n/"; /*The [i]cout[/i] is like println in java except that it needs to be told what to do. Then, [i]n/[/i] means create a new line in the command prompt voiName(); //Calls the void in the start return 0; //Makes the void do nothing but hold things } //Ends the int [i]Main[/i]
Quick things: [b]cout[/b] - prints things, but needs to be told when to create a new line [b]void[/b] - its public until you tell it its not public, it also handles things [b]n/[/b] - when used with cout, it creates a new line [b]#include[/b] - its like importing things, just had to be called something else [b]" << << "[/b] - The whole thing, is like " + + " in java

item.title: [C++] Learn how to create a file
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

‘\n’ is a new line, not ‘n/’.

It is good that you started to learn C++, just learn much more before you try to teach others and get them into bad habits or teach them the wrong thing.

Read full topic
item.source: [C++] Learn how to create a file

item.title: [C++] Learn how to create a file
item.dc:creator: @Rog3r Rog3r
item.description:
@Rog3r wrote:

Although, you’ll have to create a compiler, this does show you how to make a file.
Next I might show you how to add ints (math)

Written 100% by Roger

#include //Prepares it for compiling

int Add (int x2, int y2) { // Creates a int that is x2, and y2
cout << "Hello " << x2 << " and " << y2 << " "; /The code << y2 << is like the same as doing
" + intHere + ", you can add any int in between the << and it’ll write the int’s value/
} //Ends the int ADD

void voiName() { //Since its called in the start, anything below is for the void that is going to be called
cout << “n/This void was called.n/”; /This will only display when its called, and it’ll be on a new fresh line
as the n/ is called to create a new line./
} //This ends the void

int main() { //This is the main int, it holds everything, its like the server.java except it does nothing but hold

cout << “Chat things here.n/”; /*The cout is like println in java
except that it needs to be told what to do. Then, n/ means create a new line in the command prompt

voiName(); //Calls the void in the start
return 0; //Makes the void do nothing but hold things
} //Ends the int Main

Quick things:

cout - prints things, but needs to be told when to create a new line
void - its public until you tell it its not public, it also handles things
n/ - when used with cout, it creates a new line
#include - its like importing things, just had to be called something else
" << << " - The whole thing, is like " + + " in java

Read full topic
item.source: [C++] Learn how to create a file
